node.title: Turning Back the Clock
node.alt: A bookmobile in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, in 1967.Â
node.description: After a busy week, we offer six stories that caught our eyes.
node.content: ["After a busy week of news \u2014 elections, Supreme Court arguments, the World Series and, alas, a never-ending pandemic \u2014 today\u2019s newsletter is going to try something different. My colleagues and I will tell you about six stories that we can\u2019t stop thinking about and that you may have missed this week.", "They are a mix of long and short, from The Times and not. If you have a little time, we recommend reading any that intrigue you. If you don\u2019t, we hope you enjoy our curation. We think that the stories capture some of the undercurrents of American life right now.", "And have a good weekend. I\u2019ll see you in your inbox on Monday.", "Airlines have canceled thousands of flights. Lines at stores \u2014 especially drugstores \u2014 have grown. Restaurants no longer carry some items, like physical menus.", "The quality of many services has deteriorated since the start of the pandemic \u2014 a problem that the NPR show \u201cPlanet Money\u201d has labeled \u201cskimpflation.\u201d This deterioration, in turn, is feeding Americans\u2019 dissatisfaction with the state of the economy, as well as with life in general and with President Biden\u2019s performance, as Helaine Olen explained in The Washington Post.", "\u201cAmericans, as I am forever fond of pointing out, view civic life through the role of consumer,\u201d Olen wrote. \u201cWe don\u2019t encounter the government every day (or at least don\u2019t believe we do), but we do shop and use in-person services almost constantly. And compared to the past, American consumption is getting both increasingly expensive and, well, decreasingly nice.\u201d", "When will the situation return to normal? Nobody knows. The answer will help determine the national mood during next year\u2019s midterm campaign.", "An extraordinary open letter appeared in a public Google Doc this spring. It was signed by 93 students at Jewish seminaries \u2014 representing nearly one-fifth of all students at the U.S. schools where they were studying \u2014 and it was harshly critical of Israel.", "The back story of that letter and the movement behind it is the subject of a Times Magazine article by Marc Tracy. The movement\u2019s members are young, progressive Jews who are rethinking their support for Israel and who ground their arguments in Jewish texts.", "They still represent a minority of American Jews; most support a Jewish state, even if they have criticisms of Israeli policy. But Marc\u2019s exploration of these young rabbis \u2014 complete with a visit to a part-kibbutz, part-summer camp in Connecticut \u2014 gets at a larger tension in the country today: In one area after another, a new generation of progressives believes that their predecessors were too accepting of injustice.", "If you don\u2019t yet have an opinion about Dormzilla, you may need one.", "Charlie Munger, a billionaire and longtime deputy to Warren Buffett, donated $200 million to the University of California, Santa Barbara, several years ago with some specific conditions. The gift would pay for a new dorm \u2014 on a campus with too little housing \u2014 that would be named for Munger and that Munger (who is not an architect) would design.", "The 11-story building was projected to house 4,500 students. About 94 percent of the units would have no access to natural light or fresh air. After a Los Angeles architect on a university advisory committee resigned in protest, the story of Dormzilla, as The Santa Barbara Independent calls it, went national. It was a tale of generational inequality and billionaire hubris.", "Or was it? In New York magazine, Choire Sicha argued that Dormzilla is actually a solution to some of our problems. We need more housing density and fewer spaces that go unused for large chunks of the day. Nobody can look out of a window while they\u2019re asleep.", "An annual holiday to honor the dead \u2014 begun in Mexico and known as D\u00eda de los Muertos \u2014 took place early this week. A typical celebration revolves around an ofrenda, an offering that includes a photograph of the deceased person.", "The Los Angeles Times suggested that readers submit a digital ofrenda and published the hundreds of responses that it received. Together, they are a poignant statement about a year with far too much illness and death.", "On Saturday night, Americans will set their clocks back one hour, but there is a growing movement against the annual fall-back tradition.", "It favors permanent daylight saving time, which would lead to lighter winter afternoons and darker winter mornings. The Times\u2019s Argument podcast hosted an expert who said that the change would reduce rush-hour vehicle accidents and energy usage. (A bipartisan group of senators has proposed a bill along these lines, and Senator Patty Murray of Washington gave a speech yesterday making the case for it.)", "Josh Barro of Insider has made the other side of the argument, writing that the sun shouldn\u2019t rise after 8 a.m. in December \u2014 and that when the U.S. tried permanent daylight saving time during the 1970s energy crisis, people hated it. Barro\u2019s message: Feel free to keep whining, but turn back your clocks.", "\u201cEven in the busiest of places, if you have a good book, you can retreat into solitude,\u201d my colleague Anika Burgess writes. \u201cAnd when you live in a city like New York, a book can be even more than a story at your fingertips. It can also be a respite, an escape, a sanctuary, a diversion and a travel companion.\u201d", "As part of its 125th anniversary celebration, The Times Book Review published photos of people sneaking some reading time around New York. You can see a couple of the photos in today\u2019s newsletter and find the whole wonderful collection here.", "To win elections defined by culture war, Democrats need a positive moral vision, says David Brooks.", "Margaret Renkl just turned 60. She feels 22.", "Maybe it\u2019s time to get rid of election polls, the pollster Patrick Murray, who misjudged the New Jersey governor\u2019s race, writes in The Star-Ledger.", "Nostalgia: The online game Neopets ruled the early 2000s. Some users are still playing.", "New music: After 14 years, Robert Plant and Alison Krauss have reunited.", "26.2 at 50: The New York City Marathon through the years.", "Modern Love: A supermarket encounter with a tall, handsome stranger.", "A Times classic: How clutter stresses you out.", "Lives Lived: Pamela McCorduck wrote \u201cMachines Who Think,\u201d a groundbreaking work on the history of artificial intelligence, which she described as \u201ca dream in urgent need of being realized.\u201d She died at 80.", "What is the future of the internet? If you ask many leaders in tech, it\u2019s the metaverse. In its simplest form, the term \u2014 coined by Neal Stephenson in his 1992 novel \u201cSnow Crash\u201d \u2014 describes an online universe that people can share together, one where the internet and emerging technologies are even more enmeshed in our lives.", "Though the concept sounds very sci-fi, glimpses of that future already exist. In video games like Roblox and Animal Crossing, players can build their own worlds and visit one another\u2019s. Virtual and augmented reality are also related to the metaverse \u2014 there are tens of millions of virtual-reality headsets in circulation, mostly for gaming. If you own an NFT or cryptocurrency, that\u2019s also a part of the metaversal experience, John Herrman and Kellen Browning wrote in July.", "The tech world is invested in the metaverse\u2019s potential for \u201csocial connection, experimentation, entertainment and, crucially, profit,\u201d they write. Last week, Facebook rebranded as Meta.", "\u201cFor now, talk of the metaverse is mainly a branding exercise: an attempt to unify, under one conceptual banner, a bunch of things that are already taking shape online,\u201d Herrman wrote this week. \u2014 Sanam Yar, a Morning writer", "Read Kevin Noble Maillard on fry bread, a dish that\u2019s a comfort food and a relic of colonial displacement for Indigenous people. And try his grandma\u2019s recipe.", "\u201cFashion wasn\u2019t anything I wanted to be involved with,\u201d the photographer Annie Leibovitz says. Yet the images in her new book, \u201cWonderland,\u201d may be her strongest work.", "\u201cSpencer\u201d is a love story, a horror movie, a psychological thriller and a Christmas movie, all in one, A.O. Scott writes in a review. (It\u2019s also about Princess Diana.)", "The hosts discussed quarterback Aaron Rodgers.", "Test your knowledge of this week\u2019s headlines and see how you compare with other Times readers.", "The pangram from yesterday\u2019s Spelling Bee was gamecock. Here is today\u2019s puzzle \u2014 or you can play online.", "Here\u2019s today\u2019s Mini Crossword, and a clue: Secret agent (three letters).", "If you\u2019re in the mood to play more, find all our games here.", "Thanks for spending part of your morning with The Times. See you Monday. \u2014 David", "P.S. Susan B. Anthony voted for president 149 years ago today, defying the law. The Times included it in a roundup of \u201cMinor Topics.\u201d", "Here\u2019s today\u2019s print front page.", "\u201cThe Daily\u201d is about the trial of Kyle Rittenhouse.", "Claire Moses, Ian Prasad Philbrick, Tom Wright-Piersanti, Ashley Wu and Sanam Yar contributed to The Morning. You can reach the team at themorning@nytimes.com.", "Sign up here to get this newsletter in your inbox."]
